title: Kellogg Lifts Outlook After Quarterly Sales Rise 9%; Food company says price increases, demand offset supply-chain, cost challenges
text:
Kellogg said it was able to mitigate a number of challenges in the quarter, from high inflation to supply-chain bottlenecks and shortages.

Organic sales, which strip out impacts from currency, acquisitions and divestitures, increased more than 12%.

The company raised its outlook for organic sales to grow between 7% to 8%, up from its previous view of about 4%. Additionally, Kellogg said it expects its adjusted operating profit to grow between 4% to 5%, up from its previous projection of between 1% to 2%.

Kellogg Chief Executive Steve Cahillane said the company expects to be able to withstand current supply-chain and cost challenges.

Kellogg joins the likes of other consumer-product companies, such as Coca-Cola Co., Hershey Co. and Unilever PLC, which makes Ben & Jerry's ice cream and Dove shampoo, that have raised prices and said consumers are continuing to purchase their products.

For the period ended July 2, Kellogg reported a fall in profit to $415 million, or 95 cents a share, compared with $504 million, or $1.11 a share, a year earlier.

On an adjusted basis, per-share earnings were $1.18. Analysts polled by FactSet were expecting adjusted per-share earnings of $1.05.

The Battle Creek, Mich.-based company said revenue rose to $3.86 billion, ahead of analyst expectations of $3.64 billion, according to FactSet.

In June, the company announced plans to break its business into three companies, aiming to help its cereal brands regain their footing in supermarkets while jump-starting its growing snack business.

Shares, up almost 15% through Wednesday's close, rose 2% in premarket trading.
